{{Discrimination sidebar}}
'''Gerontophobia''' (from [[Greek language|Greek]] γέρων - ''gerōn'', "old man"<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dge%2Frwn γέρων], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref> and φόβος - ''phobos'', "fear"<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dfo%2Fbos φόβος], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref>) is the [[Fear processing in the brain|fear]] of growing old, or a hatred or fear of the [[elderly]].<ref>[http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/nov102004/1163.pdf "Gerontophobia, Ageing and Retirement"] ''Current Science'', 10 November 2004</ref>
==Indicators== [[Ken Dychtwald]] identifies seven markers that can make up this phobia in chapter two of ''Age Wave: How the Most Important Trend of Our Time Will Change Your Future''<ref>{{Cite book | author=Dychtwald, Ken; Flower, Joe | authorlink= | coauthors= | title=Age wave: the challenges and opportunities of an aging America | date=1990 | publisher=Bantam Books | location=New York | isbn=978-0-553-34806-4 | pages=}}</ref>:
* If young is good, then old is bad * If the young have it all, the old are losing it * If the young are creative, the old are dull * If the young are beautiful then the old are unattractive * If the young are stimulating, then the old are boring * If the young are full of passion, then the old are beyond caring * If the children are tomorrow, the old represent yesterday
==Gerontophobia and ageism== Discriminatory aspects of [[ageism]] have been strongly linked to gerontophobia.<ref>Bunzel, J. H. "Note on the history of a concept-gerontophobia." Gerontologist 12:116-203.</ref> This unreasonable fear or hatred of the elderly is associated with the fact that someday all young people will grow old and that old age is associated with death. This unwillingness to accept death manifests in feelings of hostility and discriminatory acts towards the elderly.<ref>Levin, J., & Levin, W. C. (1980). Ageism, prejudice and discrimination against the elderly (p. 94). Belmont, Calif.: Wadsworth Pub. Co..</ref>
